a:3:{i:0;a:2:{s:5:"title";s:41:"Reading Passage 1 - The History of Coffee";s:7:"content";s:837:"A: Coffee originated in Ethiopia, where legend says a goat herder named Kaldi discovered the coffee plant after noticing his goats became energetic after eating its berries. The energizing effects of coffee soon spread throughout the Arabian Peninsula. B: By the 15th century, coffee was being grown in Yemen, and by the 16th century, it had reached Persia, Egypt, Syria, and Turkey. Coffee houses, called "qahveh khaneh," began appearing in cities across the Middle East and became important centers for social activity and communication. C: European travelers to the Middle East brought back stories of the unusual dark beverage. By the 17th century, coffee had made its way to Europe and was becoming popular across the continent, despite some controversy initially surrounding it.";}i:1;a:2:{s:5:"title";s:44:"Reading Passage 2 - Renewable Energy Sources";s:7:"content";s:790:"A: Solar power harnesses energy from the sun using photovoltaic panels. These panels convert sunlight directly into electricity through the photovoltaic effect. Modern solar panels can achieve efficiency rates of over 20% in commercial applications. B: Wind energy utilizes large turbines to capture kinetic energy from wind and convert it into electrical power. Wind farms can be located on land or offshore, with offshore installations typically generating more consistent power due to stronger ocean winds. C: Hydroelectric power generates electricity by using the force of moving water to spin turbines. It is one of the oldest and most established forms of renewable energy, currently providing about 16% of the world's electricity.";}i:2;a:2:{s:5:"title";s:37:"Reading Passage 3 - Urban Development";s:7:"content";s:632:"Modern urban planning emphasizes creating sustainable, livable cities. Planners focus on mixed-use developments that combine residential, commercial, and recreational spaces. This approach reduces the need for long commutes and promotes walking and cycling. Green spaces are integrated throughout urban areas to improve air quality and provide recreational opportunities. Public transportation systems are designed to be efficient and accessible, reducing reliance on private vehicles. Smart city technologies are increasingly being implemented to manage resources, reduce waste, and improve the quality of life for urban residents.";}}
